definition: lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
Serbia/Serbian/abbr. for 塞爾維亞|塞尔维亚[Sai1 er3 wei2 ya4]
strategic pass/tactical border position
to stop up/to squeeze in/to stuff/cork/stopper
to stop up/to stuff/to cope with
elderly man/father/father-in-law/neck feathers of a bird (old)
surname Weng
to lose/to miss/to fail
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]
the old man lost his mare, but it all turned out for the best (idiom); fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good/also written 塞翁失馬焉知非福|塞翁失马焉知非福
pinyin: sai4 weng1 shi1 ma3 an1 zhi1 fei1 fu2

definition: the old man lost his mare, but it all turned out for the best (idiom); fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
pinyin: sai4 weng1 shi1 ma3 yan1 zhi1 fei1 fu2

sentences.english: Losing your job was just a blessing in disguise.
sentences.chinese: 看來失去原來的工作對你來說是“塞翁失馬”啊。
災禍是福，塞翁失馬焉知非福。

sentences.english: Mr. Reisinger views the housing slump as a blessing in disguise.
sentences.chinese: 雷辛格認爲房市衰退可謂是塞翁失馬。

sentences.english: "A blessing in disguise" is a good thing that you don't recognize at first as a good thing.
sentences.chinese: “塞翁失馬”是你不認識首先是一件好事好事。

sentences.english: His fail in the match was just a blessing in disguise.
sentences.chinese: 他在比賽中的失利只是塞翁失馬。

sentences.english: It means that a bad thing may become good thing under certain condition.
sentences.chinese: “塞翁失馬”比喻事事多變，壞事可以變成好事。

definition: lit. a notch on the side of a boat to locate a sword dropped overboard (idiom); fig. an action made pointless by changed circumstances
study tirelessly (idiom, from Analects)
virtue has its rewards (idiom); one good turn deserves another
to enjoy the present (idiom); to live happily with no thought for the future/make merry while you can/carpe diem
true sentiments are seen in hard times (idiom)/you see who your true friends are when you go through tough times together/you see who your true friends are when you are in difficulties
wedding night
saying in which the second part, uttered after a pause or totally left out, is the intended meaning of the allegory presented in the first part
to review the old and know the new (idiom, from the Analects)/to recall the past to understand the future
to achieve supreme enlightenment or nirvana (Buddhism)
to recognize one's mistakes and be able to reform oneself (idiom)
extreme joy turns to sorrow (idiom); Don't celebrate too soon, things could still go wrong!
The Thirty-Six Stratagems, a Chinese essay used to illustrate a series of stratagems used in politics, war, and in civil interaction/all the possible schemes and stratagems
lit. without wind there cannot be waves (idiom); there must be a reason/no smoke without fire
compassion/empathetic
see 呂洞賓|吕洞宾[Lu:3 Dong4 bin1]
not to be repeated/not to be taken as a precedent/just this once
